abstract.p: Pacific Institute President Peter H Gleick letter, in response to Mar 16 article on climate change, says most climate scientists are no longer studying causation of climate changem, and are now studying ways to understand and reduce consequences

block.p: James L. Connaughton, head of the United States Council on Environmental Quality, was quoted in ''Climate Change Is Called Economic Threat at Talks'' (news article, March 16) as saying, ''We are still working on the issue of causation, the extent to which humans are a factor'' in global climate change. This misrepresents the strong scientific consensus that humans are already causing climate change.

James L. Connaughton, head of the United States Council on Environmental Quality, was quoted in ''Climate Change Is Called Economic Threat at Talks'' (news article, March 16) as saying, ''We are still working on the issue of causation, the extent to which humans are a factor'' in global climate change. This misrepresents the strong scientific consensus that humans are already causing climate change.

Most of us in the climate field are no longer working on causation, but on understanding and reducing the worst economic, social and environmental consequences of what now appears to be unavoidable and severe climatic change.
Peter H. Gleick President, Pacific Institute Oakland, Calif., March 16, 2005
